Good. We'll continue. So we'll continue. Last time we looked at this
binary hypothesis testing,

which is-- in some ways, it's the
essence of all of statistics.

You have-- in this case, you
have just two distributions. You observe one sample,
and the question is, which distribution
generated it, one or the other?

And if you make that
more complicated and have distributions not
on a finite number of points

but on Rn or something like
that or more complicated things and you have more
than two hypotheses,

then that's kind of most
of statistics right there. But anyway, so this is
a very simple setting.

And so the question was to
make a guess about whether--

an observation,
and an observation is like a number like 3. That's an observation.

That's what happened. And then your goal is to try
to figure out, did it come-- or guess in some
intelligent way,

did it come from this
distribution or this one? And we looked at that.

You end up with-- you have this
idea of a randomized detector. It's a policy that
says when you observe

this outcome, which distribution
do you attribute it to? And if it's-- and that you
do with a 2 by n matrix where

the columns give you the
probabilities that you announce it came from p or q, the
two different distributions.

So that's how that works. If those are all 0s and 1s,
then it's deterministic.

And you end up-- you write
this down as a bicriterion optimization problem.

There's two things
you care about, the probability of
a false-positive-- and that's Pfp--

and the probability
of a false-negative. And so-- and these
are just-- you just get these from matrix
multiplication.

And the point is
that each of these is a linear function in T. T is
what describes your detector.

Anyway, so this
problem, it turns out, is actually really quite
straightforward to solve.

If you scalarize it, so you say
that lambda now is the amount--

is the factor that
relates how much I care about false-positives
versus false-negatives

or something like
that, then it turns out it just has a super-simple
solution that looks like this.

Lambda is that weighting factor. For example, if it's 1,
it says, actually, I just

want to minimize the
number of errors, period. That would be lambda equals 1. And then the
solution is analytic,

and it's been known
since, I don't know, probably 1900 or something. And it basically
says, in that case--

and it's completely reasonable. It says, if lambda
is 1 and you want to minimize say the
total number of errors,

you would say,
well, what I would do is I will choose
the distribution which

had higher likelihood. And we'll see that
in another context. Or we've already seen it in the
context of maximum likelihood,

so that's an example of that. And the lambda allows
you to put weights on the two different
types of errors, which

I think are called type
I and type II error, but I can never
remember which is which and just look it up every
time I need to know.

Actually, usually I
try to avoid situations where people are saying things
like type I and type II error.

So I usually walk out of the
room, but if I am forced to, I will just look it up
to figure out what it is. OK.
